comments.commentBody: There are some extremely thoughtful responses here that speak directly to the points the authors made. I would be very interested to see the authors respond to them individually.

If we ever get to turn Congress completely blue again, 2010-2014 legislation from around the states will be its road-map to fixing what's very wrong. Unemployment benefits should not be subject to the whims of a state legislature.

In Florida last year unemployment benefits were cut back from 26 weeks to 20 weeks. The maximum benefit that anyone can receive is $275 a week. I do not know many if any individuals much less families that can survive on $275 a week.
IN addition effective today July 1 signed by our Govenor:
HB 655: Aimed at Orange County, where a 2014 referendum was planned, the law locks local governments from requiring employers to offer paid sick leave to workers.

Cheryl,

Social skills (like any skills) are learned by trial and error, but also by modeling and direct instruction (I think the latter methods are more important the younger the child). Human beings vary in how readily they are able to pick up social skills via each of these means. Some people just have a high EQ (emotional intelligence) - they just take it all in and figure it out. On the extreme opposite end are the autistic/aspergers, who need rules and systems to learn social behavior.

I think most kids in our culture (boys especially) need more direct instruction and high structure around social rules than they get.

Thanks for making this your first blog post. It's nice to see what people are doing with the rare opportunity they had, and to see them making good use of it. Best wishes for your trip and whatever follows for you.

Andrea E: Well of course people support some restrictions! No sane person wants to see a healthy baby killed 1 minute before birth.

But that's not what we're discussing.

zezee: "No restrictions on abortions." Not sure if you're just trolling? I think most readers here would have a problem with aborting a full-term fetus and believe there should be some restrictions placed on abortions.

I wish you had read that article a little more closely. Those numbers are taken from different questions, meaning you are counting the same people twice. The following is copy/pasted from the article by Gallup discussing that May 2013 poll:

"The resulting distribution of views shows 26% of Americans favoring legalized abortion under any circumstances, 13% favoring legality under most circumstances, 38% favoring it in only in a few circumstances, and 20% saying it should be illegal in all circumstances."

So, 39% lean more heavily toward pro-choice, and 58% lean more heavily toward pro-life.

http://www.gallup.com/poll/162374/americans-abortion-views-steady-amid-g...

The cited statistics on pro-life and pro-choice stances obscure the May 2013 Gallup Poll data on abortion support in the U.S.:
--52% of Americans approve of abortion in some or limited circumstances.
--26% of Americans approve of abortion in all circumstances.
--Only 20% of Americans oppose abortion in all circumstances.

That 78% of Americans approve of abortion in some, limited or all circumstances readily demolishes the theory that Americans do not support abortion choices. This piece cherry picks its statistics to present a distorted view.

Abortion is not a joyful experience, it is a wrenching one. But it is a needed medical procedure and the choice to abort should be made by a woman, her partner (if present) and her doctor/s.

It's possible to take an Amtrak train from San Antonio to Oklahoma City, a distance that takes eight hours or more to drive. I would love to take the train from my home in San Antonio to Ft. Worth for a day of shopping and sight-seeing, or on to Oklahoma City to see my mother. But it takes 12 hours or more to go by train.

And Amtrak's posted schedules mean nothing. The rail route is shared by passenger and freight trains, and freight has the right-of-way. So when a freight train needs the track, the passenger train is directed off to a siding to wait until the freight train passes, which could take an hour or more. The dedicated passenger rail beds were pulled up decades ago in order to make room for more highway capacity.

Of course this is the Texas/Oklahoma corridor; the only thing our political leaders seem to care about carrying across the two states is bitumen through the Keystone XL pipeline. This is the reality of most of America.

Also labor economics seem pretty close to the heart of the matter one would think. I hope you're not dismissing that. I get it, though, that you're concerned with limited resources vs the population bomb.

But in any case, I appreciate your taking the time to respond, clarify, & reiterate your points.

It's always intriguing to hear the statement "this is not what the founders intended". Can anyone seriously maintain that the founding fathers were clairvoyant and foresaw the multi-cultural world we live in today, with all the technology and security threats?

For example, the Constitution mentions that the federal government should maintain a Navy and Army. No mention of an Air Force. The founding fathers could not have imagined flying machines, let alone such machines becoming an important part of warfare. Should we then not maintain an Air Force just because the founding fathers did not envision this?

DOMA was indeed overturned, at least section 3, the part that said for purposes of federal law, only opposite-sex marriages are recognized.  The only other operative part was section 2, which says that states do not have to recognize other states' same-sex marriages.  The opinion isn't clear as to whether Section 2 is also struck down; Kennedy specified that only section 3 was at issue in this case, but a lot of the language in this intentionally extremely vague opinion sounds like the entire DOMA was struck down.  Anyway, DOMA didn't state that "there is no constitutional right to marry" (although logically its constituonality would depend on that being true), so that wasn't there for the court to overturn.

In order for a politician to feel shame, they'd have to have empathy and a sincere love of the public they are serving. They have neither, nor do they want to have it.

There is a reason that none of them condemned Mitt Romney for his 47% comments. They fully agreed with him.

The politicians in today's GOP are nothing like their counterparts of the New Deal. This crop is far meaner and devoid of morals. They are more cynical and there is no depth to which they won't stoop. They're consumed with masturbating fetuses, raising the interest rate on the student debt that has now surpassed credit card debt, and if you'd let them, they would do away with Pell grants.

The only pressure that will work on Boehner, McConnell, Ryan, et al. is voting as many of their caucus as humanly possible. Senator Wendy Davis may have started a revolution in Texas. Senator Nina Turner has been doing the same in Ohio. We have Reverend William Barber of the NAACP in North Carolina. There are others in other states. We need to get in touch with them and offer them our support.

We need a voter revolt. The time to negotiate with the GOP ended in 2010. While we may be a bit late to the game, we can still win it in 2014.

Who will guard the guards themselves?
Look up Marbury v. Madison.  Google it if you have no other sources of legal opinions.  Issue settled long ago.

I love when people who are entirely ill-informed (like 99% of the commenters on this thread) make statements like this. From the Constitution:

The judicial Power of the United States, shall be vested in one supreme Court, and in such inferior Courts as the Congress may from time to time ordain and establish. The Judges, both of the supreme and inferior Courts, shall hold their Offices during good Behavior, and shall, at stated Times, receive for their Services a Compensation which shall not be diminished during their Continuance in Office.

That's life tenure, so no age or term limits. ACCORDING TO THE CONSTITUTION. I know most people with opinions hate facts that contradict their opinions, but please, just read the Constitution ONCE.

When will Congress and the Executive branch affirm their equality and end this continuous abdication of their rights to the Supreme Court? No where in the Constitution does the Supreme Court has the final say on every issue in this democracy.

It's time to enact legislation to impose age or term limits on these justices. Maybe they'll try to overturn that one too.

I won't be surprised if Florida is next to pass the same unemployment bill as North Carolina. In fact, I won't be surprised to see a bunch of states do it. That's how ALEC and the GOP has been doing business.

As F. Scott Fitzgerald so aptly noted, the rich look down on everyone else because they truly believe they are better/superior.  That is what drives many of them; that is what gives them (sorely unwarranted) confidence; and it is what distorts how they see the world.

From where I'm sitting, a healthy percentage of the self-righteousness, arrogance and myopia is coming from the Left.

Pity you can't seem to see it yourself.

You should try having a few million dollars in the bank, a fully paid off apartment in NYC would a handful of millions, and a couple of ivy league degrees plus a resume that includes McKinsey/Goldman and the like. You feel pretty darn immune.

How anyone can feel so confident and immune to economic vicissitudes that they would look down upon the working class with smugness is hard enough to fathom, but how large swaths of the middle class can view other working class Americans that way is the mother of all mysteries. Despite all of their self-righteousness, conservatives somehow can't wrap their minds around the idea that bad things happen to good people, and they are blissfully unaware that near record numbers of Americans have been unemployed for near record periods, or that others are barely employed and also living in dire straits.

Surely the wealthy elites have relatives or friends not doing so well, but they are apparently oblivious to anyone's pain but their own. Unfortunately, tasting their own bitter medicine is the only thing that might bring some of the elites down from their high horses, so for the sake of everyone else, please join me in praying that abject misery sets upon them. Millions of people longing and praying for the same thing together can't hurt and it just might help. Perhaps this kind of prayer doesn't sound like the prayers you learned when you were younger, but if you truly believe in divine intervention, then you also believe that you've already been forgiven for your sins.

I am so sorry for your loss. My dad died last year at the same age as yours. Having a parent live to an advanced old age most assuredly does not make the loss any easier to bear.  May you have peace in this difficult time,  and joyful memories once the pain subsides.

There may be an element of that, Joel. But what there is a lot of is misinformation and rank ignorance - most of which we can attribute directly to Fox News and a failing education system. Someone actually tweeted at me "the Post Office can't even manage to make money when they have a monopoly on stamps." It's really hard to have conversations with people like that when what they know and what you know - facts - are pulled from completely different databases.
